titleproper.value:
Richard Moser Research Files: GI Anti-Vietnam War Movement and Lordstown (Ohio) Automobile Workers
                    <num>TAM.544</num>

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2012-03-29T19:59-0400</date>

unittitle.value: Richard Moser Research Files: GI Anti-Vietnam War Movement and Lordstown (Ohio) Automobile Workers

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
Richard Moser was an associate professor of American history at Middle Tennessee State University until 1998, and the author of 
                <emph render="italic">The New Winter Soldiers: GI and Veteran Dissent during the Vietnam Era</emph> (1996). About one half of the collection consists of oral histories on audiocassettes the majority pertaining to the GI anti-Vietnam War movement, with some pertaining to rank and file labor movement activity during the 1970s at the Lordstown, Ohio General Motors plant there, whose workers were represented by United Automobile Workers Local 112. (Many interviews have summaries and/or transcripts.) There are also research notes, some correspondence, printed ephemera, and papers written by Moser's students. One box of GI anti-Vietnam War serials were separated to the Library's print collection, as was one box of books and pamphlets.

p.value: With the exception of the audiocassettes and videocassettes, the collection is open for research without restriction. To listen to selected audiocassettes or to view selected videocassettes, arrangements must be made with the Library for the creation of user copies, which are for research purposes only.

Richard Moser earned his PhD from Rutgers University in 1992. Until 1998, he was an associate professor of American history at Middle Tennessee State University. He is the author of 
                <emph render="italic">The New Winter Soldiers: GI and Veteran Dissent during the Vietnam Era</emph> (1996) and, with Van Gosse, is coeditor of 
                <emph render="italic">The World the Sixties Made: Politics and Culture in Recent America</emph> (2003). He has also served as the National Organizer, American Association of University Professors.

About one half of the collection consists of oral histories on audiocassettes (there are also summaries and some transcripts), most pertaining to the GI anti-Vietnam War movement, with some pertaining to rank and file labor movement activity during the 1970s at the Lordstown, Ohio General Motors plant, whose workers were represented by the United Automobile Workers Local 112. (Some interviews were conducted contemporaneously, others subsequently.) There are also research notes, some correspondence, printed ephemera, and papers written by Moser's students. One box of GI anti-Vietnam War serials were separated to the Library's print collection, as was one box of books and pamphlets. Box contents: 1. Lordstown oral histories; 2. Vietnam GI movement oral histories; 3. Vietnam GI movement oral histories; 4. Vietnam War videocasettes: documentaries; 5. Vietnam GI movement research files, including interview summaries and transcripts; 6. Lordstown research files, including interview summaries and transcripts. 
                <emph render="bold">Note:</emph> some interviews may lack summaries and/or transcripts.

corpname.value: International Union, United Automobile, Aerospace, and Agricultural Implement Workers of America. Local 1112 (Lordstown, Ohio).
